Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Portable, Miniaturized Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer featuring Autonomous In Situ Alignment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop a next-generation handheld Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. Handheld FTIR devices have opened up the possibility of interrogating samples on complex and difficult-to-access surfaces in many fields. Significantly reducing the size and weight of the handheld FTIR system will enable direct sampling in a greater number of applications that cannot be served with current devices. This new technology has relevance for laboratory and in-field forensic science analyses (narcotics identification, clandestine drug laboratories, trace evidence); cleanliness analysis in pharmaceutical and food processing environments; analysis of pharmaceutical ingredients development and potential counterfeits; chemical reaction monitoring; raw materials and finished products verification; aerospace (validation of composite bonding repairs); and chemical/explosives detection and threat screening (defense, homeland security, transportation, ports and borders). However, current devices suffer from shortcomings related to critical ergonomic factors: bulk, size, weight, user interface, and balance. These problems prevent the potential for large-scale acceptance and use of the technique. There is a need for a truly handheld (smartphone-sized), lightweight, high-performance FTIR spectrometer system capable of non-destructive, in situ analysis of a large variety of surfaces and materials.

The intellectual merit of this project is in the development of truly handheld Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectrometer. The systemic optical, opto-mechanical, electro-mechanical, and electrical circuit design of the device must be harmoniously optimized to achieve target size and configuration while still providing high performance measurements. Autonomous in situ alignment will provide better spectroscopy performance and instrument stability for use in any spatial orientation. Without this self-healing, robustness feature, a palm-sized instrument of requisite capability, precision, and resistance to shock could not possibly be contemplated. Through use of modern mobile computing technology, the unit will be unsurpassed in ease of use, integration with modern web-based media, and wireless interconnectivity. Development of highly efficient circuits and controls will facilitate the capability to run on commercial-off-the shelf (COTS) batteries. The purpose of this project is to begin the process of designing and developing the electronics, optical and opto-mechanical components required for the proposed spectrometer. This will be achieved by developing a breadboard for the overall system design, and investigating the miniaturization of FTIR components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pursuant to the Phase I research goals, a fully functional, broad band, mid-range FTIR system was designed and packaged into a pocket sized, cell phone configuration.  Performance evaluation and applications testing was accomplished with outstanding spectroscopic results.  An innovative self-healing alignment concept, “autonomous in-situ alignment,” (AIA) was contemplated and prototyped.  Two different mirror drive systems were implemented to benchmark performance to research goals.  We look forward to Phase II with great alacrity, and the potential for this innovative instrument to parallel the market impact cell phones have had on the telecommunications space. The goal of this Phase I SBIR project was to demonstrate proof-of-concept and feasibility of developing a smartphone-sized, high performance FTIR analyzer through the design, fabrication, and testing of system components to produce a smaller, less expensive, more accurate spectroscopy analyzer and mitigate technology risk from a product development project. 

The Phase I deliverables included:

1.   The development and testing of an “autonomous in-situ alignment” (AIA) breadboard to assess feasibility of a self-aligning optical system design. 

2.   The development and testing of a miniature FTIR spectrometer breadboard to prove FTIR system miniaturization feasibility. The elements below were designed, fabricated, integrated, and tested:

•             miniature optical system from source to detector.

•             miniature interferometer.

•             low power sources to test validity of size and performance goals

•             room temperature detector(s) to test validity of size, cost, and  performance goals.

•             miniature diamond Attenuated Total Reflectance sample interface technology for high spectroscopy performance

 

A future handheld, battery-powered smartphone-sized FTIR spectrometer product will enable mid-infrared out-of-laboratory applications, such as in-field or on-line/at-line production analysis. Benefits include real time analysis, yield improvement, cost/time savings and better quality control.  The ability to have a smaller, lighter, and more accurate FTIR spectrometer will promote a host of societal benefits in regard to scientific advancement and increasing safety across multiple industries. The solutions that a next generation miniaturized FTIR spectrometer can provide will literally save lives through identifying lethal chemicals, explosives, narcotics, adulterants in foods or pharmaceuticals, or drugs with no active ingredient.  The near real-time answers that this instrument can provide will save time and money by keeping critical infrastructure functioning, and by using expert resources only when necessary. Scientific advancement will be achieved through the ability to conduct more rapid and detailed testing in research both inside and outside of the laboratory environment. In addition, forensic scientists will benefit from the ability to quickly identify and process narcotics and trace evidence.  Safety will be enhanced in the pharmaceuticals industry as this next generation, miniaturized FTIR spectrometer will lead to more precise detection of counterfeit drugs and help to confirm cleanliness standards in drug processing.  And lastly, society as a whole will benefit from increased increases in speed, ease, and accuracy in the detection of hazardous materials and chemicals, promoting increased safety and security for the public.
